Identifying Characteristics: Shell color ranges from dark brown to tan and can even be black
Shell often becomes covered with mud and algae as time goes on
Tail has sharp ridges running along its length and is almost as long as the shell
Necks, legs, and tails have a yellowish color and the head is dark
Mouth is shaped like a strong, bony beak with no teeth
Skin is rough with characteristic bumps (tubercles) on their necks and legs
Feet are webbed and have strong claws
Cannot pull their head and legs into their shell for protection
Size: typically between 8’’ and 18’’ in length
Biology: Mating lasts from April through November—peak laying season is in June and July
Females can hold sperm for several seasons, using it as necessary
Females travel over land to find sandy soil in which to lay their eggs—often far from water
Female digs a hole and typically deposits 25 to 80 eggs each year with hind feet and covers eggs with sand for incubation and protection
Incubation time ranges from 9 to 18 weeks
Hatchlings can overwinter in the nest
Extremely cold-tolerant—some do not hibernate, but remain active under the ice during the winter
Lifespan is poorly known but can be recorded at around 100 years
Diet: Eat both plant and animal matter as aquatic scavengers and ambush hunters
Habitat: Water with muddy bottoms and lots of vegetation so that they can hide more easily
Can be found basking on logs in Spring
Range: Nearctic region—Southern Alberta and east to Nova Scotia in Canada and south to the Gulf of Mexico to Texas
